III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10145 Admission; policy and procedure
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedure which governs the reception and orientation of
newly admitted residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was being held with a warrant at the facility and wouldn't
release him. It is alleged that the court operated facility cannot
detail youth with a warrant from the courts.
Youth B was allegedly detained at the facility after his case was
dismissed and there no longer was an order for detention.
Investigation Interviews:
I left a message for Complainant on 7/29/25 and 8/14/25. No
return call was received.
On 7/29/25, I interviewed Administrator via telephone and
completed a follow up on 8/5/25 face to face at the facility.
Administrator reported the facility is a court operated facility.
Administrator reported youth are received from circuit court and
district court. Youth that come from the circuit court have a “pick
up order” that allows the detainment of youth at the facility. If the
youth come in from the district court (adult court), then the youth
are detained with a warrant. The youth are rarely sent directly
from district court to the facility, but it does happen on occasion.
The “pick up order” and the warrant hold the same authority; one
is just used with minor children coming from the circuit court and
the latter with youth charged as adults. For circuit court, youth are
usually arraigned 24-48 hours and then a court order for continual
stay or release is issued. For district court, they would hold the
youth until their preliminary hearing, or a release is provided by
the courts.
Administrator reported Youth A was received from the circuit court
on 7/11/25. He was given an order to detain Youth A with a 5-day
waiver. On 7/16/25, a warrant was ordered by the district court to
detain at the facility. This was completed at approximately
3:30pm. In the evening Judge came to facility at 6:30pm and
conducted a preliminary hearing to ensure Youth A’s detainment.
Not only did Youth A have the warrant to hold him there but also
the court order. On 7/17/25, a formal hearing was completed for
Youth A, and he was released on a tether.
Youth B was received from circuit court on 1/3/25. They had an
order to detain, and his next circuit hearing was to be completed
on 1/29/25. On 1/21/25, a warrant was entered by the court to
detain Youth B. Youth B was already detained. A waiver hearing
was completed on 1/24/25 where he was waved over to district
court. In this situation there was an overlap of district and circuit
2

jurisdiction, but either way, they had authority from the courts to
detain Youth B.
Documents Reviewed:
Program Statement: Licensed Court Operated facility for the
purpose of supporting justice and public safety by providing short
term programming for male and female youth ages 10-18 years of
age and who are court ordered into the Justice Center pending the
court’s disposition of the youth’s case.
Youth A:
• Order After Preliminary Hearing dated 7/11/25 to detain
Youth A until 7/16/25, resumption of the preliminary
hearing.
• Detention Order (circuit court) dated 7/16/25 to release
Youth A at 4:26pm and district court warrant to detain
youth.
• Pretrial Release Order dated 7/17/25 to release Youth A.
• Release Summary dated 7/17/25. Youth A was released to
his grandmother.
Youth B:
• Circuit Court Petition dated 1/3/25 noted to detain Youth
B at the facility.
• Notice of Hearing dated 1/3/25; Youth B is to remain
detained pending his next hearing. Next hearing is 1/29/25.
• District Court Pretrial Release Order dated 1/24/25.
Facility was to detain Youth B until bond of $50,000 was
made. The order expires on 7/24/25.
• District Court Pretrial Release Amended Lein
Expiration Date dated 6/4/25, extended the order to detain
Youth B “until bond is posted and the terms and conditions
specified in item 5 are acknowledged…”
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. The agency is licensed as
a court operated facility. The facility detains youth based on court
orders. Both Youth A and Youth B were court ordered to be
detained at the facility. Youth B is still in placement due to not
completing the requirements in the court order, bail $50,000. All
orders give the facility legal authority to detain youth, whether
coming from circuit court or district court.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
